title: Conasprella jaspidea
text:
Conasprella jaspidea, common name the Jasper cone, is a species of <a href="sea%20snail">sea snail</a>, a small <a href="cone%20snail">cone snail</a>, a marine <a href="gastropod">gastropod</a> <a href="mollusk">mollusk</a> in the <a href="family%20%28biology%29">family</a> <a href="Conidae">Conidae</a>, the <a href="Conus">cone snails</a> and their allies.
Like all species within the genus "Conasprella", these cone snails are <a href="predatory">predatory</a> and <a href="venomous">venomous</a>. They are capable of "stinging" humans, therefore live ones should be handled carefully or not at all.
Distribution.
This marine species occurs in the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a> and in the <a href="Caribbean%20Sea">Caribbean Sea</a> (off Guadeloupe); in the Atlantic Ocean off Northern <a href="Brasil">Brasil</a>.
Description.
The maximum recorded <a href="gastropod%20shell">shell</a> length is 30 mm.
Habitat.
The minimum recorded depth for this species is 0 m; maximum recorded depth is 97 m.
